intro: Serrafalcus pratensis, commonly known as the meadow serragin, is a flowering plant native to temperate regions of Europe. It belongs to the family Primulaceae and is characterized by its distinctive serrated leaves and clusters of small, white or pinkish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, grassy habitats such as meadows and stream banks. It is known for its delicate appearance and is often found in early successional stages of vegetation. Serrafalcus pratensis plays a role in supporting local pollinators and is of interest in ecological and botanical studies.
